meeting_annotations.speaker: Eva Nichols
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, also electrode fouling can be a big problem if you have the bacteria that are dying in that system. They're nice because they sort of you know can regrow and and regenerate themselves but then they do die and can sink onto your electrode and hamper sort of the the release of hydrogen or whatever product off the electrode. I would say also though that in terms of from an electrochemical standpoint, making carbon-carbon bonds is generally really challenging and copper surfaces are one of the only ones that we have that can do that well. Whereas if you're looking at organisms, they're essentially as photosynthetic organisms or chemoautotrophic organisms, essentially they have to make carbon-carbon bonds otherwise they won't survive. So I think that could be a really big benefit for combining electrochemical and biological hybrids.

The problem is nobody knows if all that carbon actually makes it all the way down to the bottom of the ocean and gets sequestered and buried or whether it gets consumed and remineralized and taken back up to the surface as CO2. That's a very difficult problem to solve.
